The only reason I left was to be closer to real family.
cons: Worked short many times, with 6 patients and no tech, which they were in the process of resolving when I left. Many units were short, so we would have to float to other units. The admin folks are basically incompetent as they know nothing of healthcare and what drives a practice. They are only interested in the “bottom line”.

job_title: ICU Registered Nurse in Chattanooga, TN
pros: Amazing coworkers, strong nurses and a great team-like atmosphere among the providers and nurses. The job itself is challenging and forces you to "grow up" quickly. Level one trauma center and teaching hospital with a large variety of learning opportunities.
cons: Toxic upper management/CEO, no covid hazard pay, forced to float to other units all the time without compensation, asked to wear n95 for 7 shifts before disposing of it, one "raise" in the last 10 years, continuously cutting benefits, always short staffed in all departments making a sensible workflow impossible, most equipment is broken or lost, constant employee turnover with NO efforts made to retain nurses.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Chattanooga, TN

review_title: Zero concern or regard for health and well-being of employees
pros: Some great coworkers, most coworkers are hard working and do a good job
cons: Absolutely zero concern for the health and well-being of employees. We are living through the first pandemic of our time and generation, and as a HOSPITAL in the middle of a pandemic, if an employee of Erlanger tests positive for COVID, they CANNOT use their own sick time to cover their REQUIRED quarantine days until they are better unless they use an entire week’s worth of PTO first??!!!!?? Are you kidding me???? One of the most essential places there is in this pandemic and their own employees can’t use their sick time when they are sick with the one thing that caused an entire worldwide pandemic??!!! So use all your PTO, now you can’t take time off so you get burnt out. Use all your PTO and if you don’t have any then tough luck on getting paid for having COVID of all things! If a pandemic illness isn’t a good enough reason for employees to be able to use their sick time, then I don’t know what is. That’s the most absurd thing I’ve ever heard of, and frankly, what’s the point in anyone even taking precautions of COVID if they know they’re getting screwed on paying bills if they can’t even use sick time for testing positive on such a MAJOR virus? What is wrong with this picture, Erlanger????!!!! 80% of all other businesses will pay, cover, or allow employees to use sick time if they have a positive COVID test, yet a hospital whose employees put themselves at risk for COVID every day can’t use sick time if they end up getting COVID.

pros: Working there gives knowledge. Everyday is a chance to learn if you treat it that way. You work closely with nurses and doctors, and have the opportunity to ask tons of questions and watch many things. The benefits aren't too bad
cons: Way too under staffed!! Most days you come in you have 19 patients and on a good day you have 13. It's way too many patients to actually provide adequate care. Then it's always our fault and pressuring us to meet industry standards on the lowest of staffing numbers. The nurses are also very short handed with 8 patients some days. The equipment is very old and outdated, and they are only giving anything new to one of the newly built wings on a campus in another part of the city. They put very little money into each floor. The overall look and quality doesn't feel very advanced as they would like for you to believe. The pay isn't that great I get paid less than a unit clerk who has absolutely no formal training for their job, and received no experience pay.

pros: Great, meaningful job and interesting work.

review_title: Innovation and trauma one experience without any compensation or gratitude
job_title: Registered Nurse, Critical Care in Chattanooga, TN
pros: Trauma one center with exciting new cases and learning opportunities, teaching hospital, many areas and specialized job openings
cons: No raises, no bonuses, extremely low staffing ratios, no incentive or call back pay for overtime despite low staffing, lack of hiring experienced nurses, stalling or lack of opportunities to grow or internal transfers, high nurse turnover after less than 2 years of working

review_title: Cannot wait to escape from here.
pros: The insurance benefits are okay, but it seems each year, the coverage and network shrinks while the cost increases. Some of my co-workers are great, others not so much.
cons: Every day is stressful and a challenge. My department is GROSSLY understaffed. As people leave, the work is simply put on the backs of the employees still there with no increase in pay. The division of work is not balanced in my department. I am doing the work that four people used to perform (I wish I could say I'm exaggerating...I'm not), while others in my department can slack off and take three lunches and multiple other breaks throughout the day. Most days, my lunch is eaten at my desk while I'm working, and I'm lucky to get a couple of bathroom breaks. Management is clueless and out of touch with the peons breaking their backs doing the actual work. All they care about is the bottom line.

review_title: Great place to work if you can tolerate management bullying.
pros: Great learning environment, newest advances and state of the art medical technology.  Lateral movement opportunities, recent collaboration with Vanderbilt should be helpful.
cons: Management have huge egos and are allowed to get away with work place bullying.  HR turns a blind eye and does nothing to help staff that are victims of abusive bosses.  C suite level has demoralized long term loyal employees by stealing extended illness bank hours that many were relying on upon retirement. Not much opportunity for advancement unless you are part of the inner circle.

job_title: Central Dispatch Technician in Chattanooga, TN
pros:
- if you're looking to further your knowledge for a more in depth career in the medical field, you would be hard-pressed to find a place better suited, in terms of patient load and variety and attitude towards education, than erlanger baroness campus. Whether you are a tech or transporter, you will be in close contact with patients of all sorts. 
- the pay is always above minimum wage
- central dispatch is an amazing department. The work load is more reasonable than other's, and the management is agreeable and friendly.
cons: - it is exceedingly busy. The patient turnover is ridiculous, and every position there has to keep up. As a transporter you will walk your legs off.

pros: Great Co-Workers, RN's are encouraged to do what is best for their patients, but the nurse to patient ratio is outrageous. Most nurses have to stay WAY beyond their shift to catch up on paperwork and other non nursing functions they are commanded to perform, because there are too many non-hands-on people.
cons: There are too many Management type people. Why does this complex need 19 vice presidents and associate vice presidents plus department heads plus assistant department heads plus? Every vice president doesn't hold the title of V.P., but they are paid the salary just the same.  It is ridiculous how many NON-hands on people there are around here. These people hunt for things to do, or they hide in their small offices. When they do come out of hiding, they try to micromanage what they stumble upon. Top heavy management and not enough hands on bedside people.

review_title: Great place to learn but management is bad
pros: Erlanger is a great place to learn as an RN. I have worked here for over 6 years. There are a lot of great employees with wonderful teamwork and personalities.
cons: The main issue with Erlanger is how bad the upper management treats staff. There are continuously more and more silly and unreasonable expectations of the staff but without any decent compensation. Erlanger pays their lower employees such as environmental services, patient care techs, and RNs meager wages, while upper management makes sickening amounts. Recently, CEO Kevin Spiegel received a 25% salary increase, in addition to bonuses, while employees had their first raise of 2% in years. In addition, lower management doesn’t understand why they can’t keep around nurses more than a year at the hospital.

pros: Payroll deduction for car insurance
cons:
There is no cohesiveness among staff. Pettiness and clicks are evident. There is a BIG LACK OF COMMUNICATION.  The pay is ridiculous 11.18 thats if you're an emt, ma, first responder for nights and shift diff. You may get close to 11.30. So dont worry about the experience you may have. The 11.18 is across the board. Other hospitals i interviewed with laughed and shook their heads at the pay. 
A break doesn't exists just eat when you can. Always short staffed. Felt bad for nurses and paramedics at times. The manager over everyone never knew what was going on half of the time. She was more worried about what she can catch you doing instead of asking what can help to fix a issue. No moral what so ever.

pros: Good staff to work with, docs are nice for the most part, challenging cases, rarely boring.
cons: Management here is horrible. They seem to make the rules up as they go, and one week they're threatening to fire people over something, the next week it's forgotten. The way they talk to some people is unbelievable, and there is no fairness. Some people are written up at the drop of a hat, others can get in fights at work, yell at coworkers and management, etc., and nothing happens. Also very unstable environment, full time employees are not getting their hours, people are told they are lucky just to keep their jobs.

pros: We are a level 1 trauma center and a teaching hospital. We have the number one stroke center in the Southeast. I love the fact that we are constantly striving to improve patient care and surgical procedures. Our current CEO has turned this hospital around from serious challenges. Our atmosphere is one of "it is okay to ask questions, we rather you ask than make a mistake".  I love that.  Great health benefits, some of the most affordable I know of.  Employee benefits like insurance, retirement accounts etc are really good.
cons: the culture is still in transformation with our new leadership. There is a lingering mistrust of the upper management but I believe that in time it will lessen. certain departments of hospital seem less organized than others.

review_title: Work here if you don't want to make money
pros: Benefits, great doctors, Starbucks
cons: The pay is HORRIBLE for MA's that do so much. A patient service representative makes more than some MA's and I think that's ridiculous bc of all the schooling and training we went through just to even get the title. Management sucked where i  worked at and she only picked her favorites. The doctor i  worked for was great but there was no reason for me to stay over some days, and not get paid anything. We always got on to because we had overtime hours, but sometimes we had to stay over bc our doctor was still seeing patients! But yet there are REGISTERED NURSES that stay over all the time and still do. Maybe that's why they can't pay MA's more!!

pros: good benefits, my manager is great.  cost of living very reasonable.  manager flexible with time off and if you work extra hours because of issues or projects, will give you time off.  previously, would let any department purchase any machinery without second thought and then expect analyst to support without knowing anything.  Wasted lots of money , but now with Epic was more manageable.
cons: some old school thoughts of doing things can hinder progress.   sometimes people don't listen to non-managerial employees.

pros: The coworkers are generally great to work with, as are the doctors. Challenging level 1 trauma. Making a difference to some of the poorest people in the region.
cons: Management, no doubt. Low salaries, despite challenging environment at a level one trauma center. Zero paid holidays, you're forced to use PTO anytime you take off, even during holidays when your department is closed. Management makes ridiculous salaries and bonuses while RNs have lowest salaries in the region. They act like they're doing you a huge favor giving 1-2% raise every few years. The only perks come from other companies in the area which offer discounts to erlanger employees.

pros: Over the past 10+ years Erlanger has been through a lot of change. Finally, with a new CEO they are heading in the right direction. Staff are getting the raise they deserve (up to par with local hospitals), if not better. Erlanger has also been able to tap into "lost funds"from the government, preventing more debt and allowing for improvements within the hospital.
cons: There is a poor process for removing incompetent people. It almost takes an act of congress to get someone fired or to leave. Complaints have to be piled high before any action is taken.

pros: The most positive thing I can say is that I am no longer employed at Erlanger Health System. There are good people from time to time but they don't last long. I had a couple of great bosses when I was there and there were some executives who actually cared about people, but they're all gone now.
cons: The environment is the most toxic imaginable. There is no respect for the individual and they waste money on ridiculous "programs" to improve employee satisfaction. I remember when they hired experts to come in and teach employees how to be nice. Thousands upon thousands of dollars later, and penalizing employees for not carrying papers to remind them to be nice to each other, it didn't make an ounce of difference in the toxicity that hovers there.

review_title: One hard thankless job! Common nursing critique but even more so in Chattanooga.
pros: Nurse: autonomy, learning experience at a trauma 1 center, summertime in a river city.
cons: Lower than average salary, slow pay raises, selfish prioritizing by administration of profit after the FIRST profitable year in decades, antiquated equipment, "skeleton crew" staffing of high patient flow departments.

pros: Get to see so many unique cases, as every hospital in our region transfers any harder cases to us.
cons: Work with the hardest cases but with less pay than hospitals around us. Market adjustments haven’t been done in years for full time employees  with no opportunity to pick up overtime either. PRN’s recently got approx. $2+/hour more which is unfair to full time employees.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Chattanooga, TN
pros: I have worked at Erlanger for 5 years.  I have worked with AMAZING physicians, nurses, and other clinical staff at Erlanger that make coming to work rewarding despite crappy pay/benefits. I think with current CEO good changes are happening just veeeeeery slowly.
cons: Pay is not competitive and there are abundant incompetent people in positions of power. The progress that could be made is killed by the incompetent people dropping the ball.

pros: Depending on your role and department within the organization you work with a great staff. Everyone is willing to help you learn and grow. I receive a lot of exposure to new things on the administrative end. Since EHS is a teaching hospital it would be a great opportunity to take on duties and projects that build your resume.
cons: The medical benefits are a bit crappy. Erlanger has several policies in place that require employees to use only Erlanger physicians and facilities to avoid penalties.

review_title: Nice type of work, but undervalued position by management.
pros: Helping patients and providers communicate well is what it's all about. There is a lot of on the job variety and you get to see many interesting things.
cons:
Not much room for advancement. This position is undervalued but severely needed. 
There also was no incentive or support for continuing education in the field.

pros: The working atmosphere is great with helpful employees and a clean and comfortable environment to work in each day.  The physicians are excellent in providing care and following recommendations of supportive staff. The hospital has an open forum for all to share thoughts and concerns.
cons: The facility is not at market base for salary and hourly wages at this time.  Due to high costs for being a community hospital, the facility has difficulty maintaining the highest technology for nursing.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Chattanooga, TN
pros:
Level I Trauma Center, Teaching Hospital, Level IV NICU, Children's Hospital, Outpatient Clinics

A lot of variety to choose from for the region
cons: Some jobs are more difficult to get than others, depends on who you know. Management is poor, very hands off. Read The Chattanoogan if you want a fair assessment of how management and executives treat employees.

pros: Discounts on many items including major phone carriers.  Access to bariatric surgery for half cost, 10% discount in the pharmacy and cafeteria. $5 generic prescriptions at all CVS.   Farmers Market  at all locations once a week. Four locations, two with full time hospitals.
cons: Bad insurance, having to use their doctors,

pros: The co-workers are great, teams are supportive and super to work with.
cons: Pay. Salaries are way below the minimum starting pay for the same job at a level 2 hospital in the same area. High turnover of employees for this reason.

job_title: Certified Clinical Medical Assistant in Chattanooga, TN
pros:
hours not bad
plenty of potential job opportunities
good food options
Starbuck's
yup that's about it
cons:
Insulting pay rate
Management was never actually there
the co-workers were like being back in high school and the drama that comes with it
ridiculous rules/limitations for CCMA's in a practice setting not on the floor

review_title: No respect for loyalty; no consideration for promoting from within; no merit raises; turns blind eye & plays favorites;
job_title: RN Clinical Coordinator in Chattanooga, TN
pros: Patients; teaching institution; Starbucks; Vendor lunches
cons: Management across the board; does not care about the working force of the organization that hold the place together

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Chattanooga, TN
pros: Work with awesome good-natured patient hilarious people!! The entire staff at Erlanger, in all departments, are fabulous.  Just wish Erlanger treated them so.
cons:
No meaningful raises, nurse retention is not their goal, people get there 2-3 years and get out because the pay is stagnant
Short Staffed ALWAYS
New annual review process, please stop making us review ourselves

review_title: Sad experience, could have so much better
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Chattanooga, TN
pros: Some of the people that I worked with were very good
cons: Where to start...pay is horrible, management is even worse. Too much of the "because we are buddies, you will get what you want" type management going on.

review_title: Potential to be great, but too focused on politics and money
job_title: Patient Care Technician in Chattanooga, TN
pros: There are wonderful opportunities to learn and expand experience and knowledge. Amazing people to work with. Good employee perks.
cons: Understaffed. Job expectations are unrealistic and demanding and equivalent to modern day slave labor. Patient load is excessively and consistently too large and overwhelming. Will often have a ratio of 30 patients to 1 tech

review_title: Overall, I enjoy my job at Erlanger hospital.
job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Chattanooga, TN
pros: Good pay, good benefits, coworkers are good, and the hours aren't bad. Second and third shift employees get paid a shift differential in addition to their base pay.
cons: Sometimes employees don't communicate well with each other, leading to confusion and double work being done. Employees also don't have much communication with management due to differing schedules.

review_title: Never Work Here Unless You are Upper Management
pros: Some of the coworkers are amazing. Teaching hospital and level 1 so loads of experience.  Residents are great to have around 24/7.
cons:
Erlanger pays as little as it can get by with. They have pulled the rug out from the staff and retirees because of "too little profit" only to give that money in the form of huge bonuses to upper management. So obviously, moral is not good. Management literally *times* how long it takes you to do certain things, from housekeeping on up and you then have to document why it took you longer if you miss by a few minutes. Because we all know there are never any interruptions/ snark.  
I worked as an RN for a couple of decades there, btw. At one time I was proud to work there. Now they treat the staff like numbers, expect you to do the job of 3 people and not make mistakes, and the system for charting and giving drugs, etc is the most incompetent program I've ever seen or dealt with. 
Management most assuredly finds ways to get rid of the staff that have been there the longest, especially when they still paid a small pension (which they don't anymore.) Those RN's who are higher on the pay scale will be replaced with a new grad gleefully.  For example, if you are out sick/call in more than 4 times in 2, yes 2 years, you are fired. Nurses are expected to be PCT's, secretaries as well. I am certainly ready to help with anything, even housekeeping if my work is done. My point is they won't hire enough staff to keep the unit, equipment, and patients clean,  but anytime there is an infection, it's because the nurse didn't wash their hands. They actually have spies to watch you as you go in and out of rooms. But no one goes in and sees you wash your hands in front of the patient, so you get dinged for not using that horrible skin splitting alcohol rub from the bottle outside the room.  
We had some PRN nurses who also travelled, worked strikes, worked places like Grady in ATL, hospitals similar in NYC, LA, Philly... while on strike! and said it wasn't as hard as working at Erlanger. If you can work here, you can work anywhere, so don't let them take your confidence away when they tell you what a bad job you do. That's how they keep the staff that don't move on. Bust their self esteem up and make them think they could never get another job and how lucky they are to have the one they have.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Chattanooga, TN
pros: Work schedule was flexible, a lot of overtime was encouraged
cons: Poor management and leadership skills of superiors, a lack of support in career development, often negligible or intentional hostile environment

pros: There are many different ways to work as an RN within the Erlanger Health System, so it offers lots of different positions and shifts.
cons: Management rarely shares important matters with employees; we often read about things in the newspaper first. Zero dollars available for education, no physician order entry and some management positions left open for years.

review_title: Too much pay for administrators, not enough for patient care givers
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Chattanooga, TN
pros: Steady paycheck, constant supply of patients
cons: Don't feel valued...always pushed to do more with less...to the point that patients are endangered

job_title: Senior Cardiac Technician in Chattanooga, TN
pros: Work weeks are usually 36 hours, however it is easy to pick up extra shifts if you want. Management doesn't micro-manage. Health insurance benefits are great.
cons: You are able to pick up extra shifts because the department is a revolving door. The pay is terrible, so no one wants to stay.

pros: As a student nurse tech, I get a lot of experience and the RNs that I work with are always willing to help/teach!
cons: Techs do not make enough for all that they do! We didn't even get a Christmas bonus this year.

review_title: Not what I thought it would be
job_title: Patient Care Technician in Chattanooga, TN
pros:
~ Level 1 trauma center. 
~ Lots of different areas to work in
cons:

~ They are so understaffed that there is no quality patient care. Nurses and tech have to many patients to fulfill each one's needs.

review_title: work here only if you're about to have your home foreclosed
pros: there are some of the best co workers at Erlanger.
cons: the benefits are going downhill, management is only looking out for themselves and will do anything to get a bonus,

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Murphy, NC
pros: Small hospital, pay and OT availability
cons: Chronically understaffed. Please check reviews for Murphy Medical Center as well (previous name). Negative reviews are accurate. They have a clique which creates a hostile work environment which is not controlled. Workplace bullying in the form of verbal aggression, condescending remarks, exclusion, belittling, passive aggressive techniques. No improvement after discussions with management.  Public humiliation- yelling at staff in public areas by peers and/or physicians.

review_title: Extremely stressful for little pay and zero benefits, with no room to move up to a non PRN position.
job_title: Corrective Maintenance Apprentice in Chattanooga, TN
pros: One plus is very little supervision.
cons: No pay increase, no benefits, no PTO, no room to move up within company, unrealistic expectations.

pros: The women and men in the NICU were amazing staff. Lots of years of experience..
cons:
Poor pay
Erlanger health system is focused on the Physicians and not on the nurses!

review_title: Loved working for Erlanger but management was very unprofessional.
job_title: Patient Care Technician in Chattanooga, TN
pros: Learning hospital to learn a variety of new skills
cons: HR doesn’t want to help employees, pay isn’t very good for the job you do, not enough quality help and always short staffed.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Chattanooga, TN
pros: stable work, good work environment, good chance to move up with company or transfer to another area. good education opportunities.
cons: never rarely receive raises, salaries are too low should pay more for this growing hospital.management could be better .

job_title: Cardiac Surgical Technologist in Chattanooga, TN
pros: Competitive pay, great CEO, best co-workers. Flexible, vacation. Friendly easy environment to work in. Payroll deductions, insurance, retirement.
cons: Health insurance could be better. Parking isn't so great.

pros: CEO has a high level of integrity. The mission of the organization is such that they care for all, regardless of ability to pay.
cons: Going through some painful changes. Highly charged political environment within the medical staff.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Chattanooga, TN
pros: convenient location to my home
cons: untrustworthy and unreliable management team to work with or for.

pros: Teaching facility, co-workers,  team work at times
cons: Nurse to patient ratio is not safe, increase in employee turn over, unsafe environment , parking,  no working equipment

pros: Love the people I work with in my department. Love caring for the patients.
cons: There are always promises of raises, and they never deliver. They do not care about employees, just the higher ups who get the bonuses.

pros: Life at a level 1 trauma center is rough no matter what you do there. However it also attracts some of the best professionals there are.
cons: Stress levels run high and there aren't many outlets to get it out.

review_title: Respiratory Therapist at Erlanger Health System
job_title: Registered Respiratory Therapist in Chattanooga, TN

cons: They constantly run shifts short staffed and do not care about quality of patient care.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Cleveland, TN
pros: Ability to grow with education, decent insurance rates, cafeteria food is actually good, lots of diversity, quality supplies, organized hiring process

review_title: Over ten years in non-clinical support roles @ Erlanger
pros: Opportunities for learning and position transfers were available.
cons: Pay is set at time of hire and raises are only provided across the board.

pros: I've enjoyed the floor I've been on since I got here. My co-workers have been experienced and pleasant to work with.
cons: Very short staffed. All the time. Unstable management - constantly changing policies and procedures.

pros: Awesome coworkers and practice managers

pros: erlanger the people was good to work with such as doctors and nurses, also family members.

pros: I like working three twelve hour shifts a week.
